name: Later Alexandrian Scientists Quiz | Scientists & Inventors | 10 Questions

questions.text:
Hipparchus, perhaps the greatest astronomer of the ancient world, also first developed
which mathematical discipline?
questions.explanation:
Trigonometry.

	Hipparchus was the first to observe andrecord the precession of the equinoxes, and also developed a system by which eclipses ofthe moon and sun could be predicted.

questions.text:
The herbalist Crateuas and Apollonius of Citium made what contribution to the scientific
world?
questions.explanation:
Scientific sketches.

	Crateuas sketched plants with important medical applicationswhile Apollonius sketched medical operations and systems of bandaging.  Crateuas' workinfluenced the surgeon Pedanius Dioscorides, who served in the Roman legions underNero.  Dioscorides' work provided the basis for botanical research during the MiddleAges.

questions.text:
The first recorded steam engine was described in a work by which Alexandrian scientist
of the 1st century AD?
questions.explanation:
Hero.

	His simple steam engine is described in his work'Pneumatica'.  Unfortunately, few were interested in this contrivance, and the era of steampower would have to wait another 17 centuries!

questions.text:
Which Alexandrian scientist predicted that the sun, in certain circumstances, might be
visible even after it had dipped below the horizon?
questions.explanation:
Cleomedes.

	He made this predictionafter noticing the refracting effect that water has with light, and made the sameprediction regarding the earth's atmosphere, suggesting he understood the distortingeffects contained therein.

questions.text:
Rufus of Ephesus, a medical writer of the 1st century AD, was the first to identify and
describe which important part of the eye?
questions.explanation:
lens.

	Rufus named this item the'lens'...because it was shaped like a lentil.

questions.text:
One of the last of the ancient Greek mathematicians, which fellow wrote the
'Arithmetica', a work that contained the first systematic use of signs and symbols in
algebraic problems?
questions.explanation:
Diophantus.

	Unfortunately, Diophantus's work was essentially lostfor several hundred centuries, not appearing in print again until a Latin translation in1575.

questions.text:
Hypatia is the only female mathematician of antiquity known to us.  Not only was she a
professor of philosophy at Alexandria, succeeding her father, but also an experienced and
adept writer on the subject of algebra.  Who was her father, the person she replaced as
professor at the university in Alexandria?
questions.explanation:
Theon.

	Hypatia was murdered by Christianfanatics in 415 AD, tragically cutting short the career of this Neo-Platonist philosopher and mathematician.

questions.text:
What was the great mathematical and astronomical work of the ancient Egyptian scientist
Ptolemy (Claudius Ptolemaeus) called?
questions.explanation:
Almagest.

	The Almagest provided the basis forthe Earth-centered theory of the universe, not conclusively disproved until the time ofCopernicus.  The Greeks called this work the 'Megale Mathematike Syntaxis' (greatmathematical composition) or 'megiste syntaxis'.  This name was shortened andtransliterated by Arabic scholars into 'Al-magiste', from whence we get the nameAlmagest.

questions.text:
Ptolemy described a number of different astronomical instruments within his Almagest. 
Which of these instruments was used to measure the position of the moon?
questions.explanation:
Triquetrum.

	Triquetrum translates from the Latin as 'triangular'.  It could be used even when the moonwas in its various phases.

questions.text:
Galen, a scholar of Pergamum during the 2nd century AD, provided a synthesis of the
biological and medical sciences that remained the basis for Western medicine for nearly
1500 years.  One of the cornerstones of his theories regarding the human body was his
belief in bodily humors.  Which of these was not one of the four basic humors according
to Galen?
questions.explanation:
Lymph.

	The four were:  phlegm, blood, choler and melancholy.  Of the four, only blood proved tobe a true 'bodily humor'.  It really is a shame that Galen's work remained the authoritativesource in the life sciences for so long, most of it proved to be incorrect and misleading.  By the way, if you enjoyed this one please feel free to try my quiz on the earlier Alexandrian scientists...you won't be disappointed!
